{"uri": "8118421499", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:00:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:00:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T03:59:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2932713-rory-mcilroy-declines-pga-tour-board-re-election-amid-concerns", "title": "Rory McIlroy Declines PGA Tour Board Re-Election Amid Concerns | Sports-Games", "body": "Rory McIlroy has declined an offer to rejoin the PGA Tour board due to resistance from some members. Webb Simpson, who originally offered to give up his seat for McIlroy, will remain on the board. McIlroy's potential return was seen as a way to improve negotiations with LIV Golf but was met with complications. McIlroy was previously on the board but resigned due to time constraints and the PGA Tour's negotiations with Saudi backers. Despite not rejoining the board, McIlroy remains involved and has advocated for a more global schedule and collaboration between tours.\n\nRory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nSimpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat -- but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\" McIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nPGA Tour Commissioner Jay Monahan said the development \"is in no way a commentary on Rory's important perspective and influence.\" He said it was a matter of adhering to the governance process of joining the board.\n\n\"Webb remaining in his position as a member of the policy board and PGA Tour Enterprises board through the end of his term provides the continuity needed at this vital time,'' Monahan said.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said about potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\" Simpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\nMcIlroy is still likely to be involved, though not in a board capacity, given the relationships he has built on both tours. He also met with Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of PIF, last year during the DP World Tour Championship in Dubai at the end of 2022. McIlroy said on a soccer podcast in January he encouraged the PGA Tour to meet with Al-Rumayyan.\n\nThe stunning framework agreement among the PGA Tour, European tour and PIF was announced June 6.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,'' McIlroy said. ''And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8118207840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:45:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:45:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:44:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/rory-mcilroy-wont-rejoin-pga-tour-board-says-others-were-uncomfortable-with-his-potential-return/600364655/", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't rejoin PGA Tour board, says others were 'uncomfortable' with his potential return", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Rory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nSimpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat -- but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became ''pretty complicated and messy,'' which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n''I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,'' McIlroy said. ''I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.''\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nPGA Tour Commissioner Jay Monahan said the development ''is in no way a commentary on Rory's important perspective and influence.'' He said it was a matter of adhering to the governance process of joining the board.\n\n''Webb remaining in his position as a member of the policy board and PGA Tour Enterprises board through the end of his term provides the continuity needed at this vital time,\" Monahan said.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n''I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,'' McIlroy said about potentially returning the board. ''So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.''\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a ''global superstar'' and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\nMcIlroy is still likely to be involved, though not in a board capacity, given the relationships he has built on both tours. He also met with Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of PIF, last year during the DP World Tour Championship in Dubai at the end of 2022. McIlroy said on a soccer podcast in January he encouraged the PGA Tour to meet with Al-Rumayyan.\n\nThe stunning framework agreement among the PGA Tour, European tour and PIF was announced June 6.\n\n''Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,'' Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n''I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?''\n\nAP Golf Writer Doug Ferguson contributed {"uri": "8118464616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "04:42:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T04:42:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T04:40:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-rory-mcilroy-wont-rejoin-pga-tour-board-says-others-were-uncomfortable-with-his-potential-return-5951267.html", "title": "Sports News | Rory McIlroy Won't Rejoin PGA Tour Board, Says Others Were 'uncomfortable' with His Potential Return | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. Rory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nCharlotte (USA), May 9 (AP) Rory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nSimpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat -- but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nAlso Read | On Which Channel Pakistan vs Ireland 2024 Series Will be Telecast Live in India? How To Watch PAK vs IRE T20I Matches Live Streaming Online?.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nAlso Read | LSG Owner Sanjiv Goenka Caught on Camera Having Intense Conversation With KL Rahul Following 10-Wicket Defeat Against SunRisers Hyderabad in IPL 2024 (Watch Video).\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nPGA Tour Commissioner Jay Monahan said the development \"is in no way a commentary on Rory's important perspective and influence.\" He said it was a matter of adhering to the governance process of joining the board.\n\n\"Webb remaining in his position as a member of the policy board and PGA Tour Enterprises board through the end of his term provides the continuity needed at this vital time,\" Monahan said.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said about potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\nMcIlroy is still likely to be involved, though not in a board capacity, given the relationships he has built on both tours. He also met with Yasir Al-Rumayyan, the governor of PIF, last year during the DP World Tour Championship in Dubai at the end of 2022. McIlroy said on a soccer podcast in January he encouraged the PGA Tour to meet with Al-Rumayyan.\n\nThe stunning framework agreement among the PGA Tour, European tour and PIF was announced June 6.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. {"uri": "2024-05-349390687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:34:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:34:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:30:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.valleycentral.com/sports/ap-rory-mcilroy-wont-rejoin-pga-tour-board-says-others-were-uncomfortable-with-his-potential-return/", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't rejoin PGA Tour board, says others were 'uncomfortable' with his potential return", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) -- Rory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday that a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nSimpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat -- but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said of potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"", "source": {"uri": "valleycentral.com", McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said of potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. {"uri": "8117594737", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:52:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:52:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:52:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.espn.com/golf/story/_/id/40105868/rory-mcilroy-rejoin-pga-tour-board-pushback", "title": "Rory: Other players balked over return to board", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Rory McIlroy will not return to the PGA Tour's policy board as expected because of other player directors' concerns about bringing him back, McIlroy said Wednesday.\n\nMcIlroy, who resigned from the policy board on Nov. 14, was expected to replace Webb Simpson on the PGA Tour policy board and the board of directors of PGA Tour Enterprises.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations,\" McIlroy said ahead of this week's Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow Club. \"Sort of reminded me partly why I didn't [stay on the board]. So yeah, I think it got pretty complicated and pretty messy.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened, I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before. I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nSimpson, 38, will finish out his term, which expires in 2025. Simpson had hoped to step down from the boards to spend time with his family.\n\n\"I think the best course of action is if, you know, there's some people on there that aren't comfortable with me coming back on, then I think Webb just stays on and sees out his term,\" McIlroy said. \"I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that, and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nAlong with Simpson, the other player directors on the tour's policy board are Patrick Cantlay, Peter Malnati, Adam Scott, Jordan Spieth and Tiger Woods. Former tour member Joe Ogilvie is a board liaison.\n\nMcIlroy, the No. 2 golfer in the world, had joined the policy board in 2022 and was expected to serve through 2024. The 35-year-old cited personal and professional commitments in making his decision to leave the board late last year.\n\nMcIlroy's surprising reversal comes at a time when the PGA Tour is attempting to negotiate a final agreement with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, which finances the rival LIV Golf League. PGA Tour commissioner Jay Monahan and policy board player directors met with PIF governor Yasir Al-Rumayyan in the Bahamas on March 18.\n\nMcIlroy has previously met with Al-Rumayyan to discuss the future of men's professional golf. McIlroy said Al-Rumayyan wanted to do the \"right thing\" with PIF's investment in golf.\n\nHe said some PGA Tour members have voiced concerns about potentially playing a global schedule outside the U.S. and whether to allow golfers who left for LIV Golf to come back to the tour.\n\nWith Simpson staying on the policy board, McIlroy said he is \"still optimistic\" that a deal with the PIF can get done.\n\n\"I think Webb staying on is a really good thing,\" McIlroy said. \"I think he's got a really balanced voice in all of this, and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great. My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen? Yeah, I'm really happy that Webb has made that decision to stay on and serve out the rest of his term.\"\n\nMcIlroy, who grew up in Northern Ireland, said both sides will have to compromise in good faith to get a deal done. He is frustrated that a deal hasn't been finalized because \"we've got this window of opportunity to get it done.\"\n\nWhile discussing what would have to happen to bring the fractured sport together, McIlroy invoked the Good Friday Agreement of April 10, 1998, which ended political unrest in Ireland and Northern Ireland that had occurred since the 1960s.\n\n\"Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace, and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\" McIlroy said. \"That was in 1998 or whatever it was, and 20, 25, 30 years ahead, my generation doesn't know any different. It's just this is what it's always been like, and we've never known anything but peace.\n\n\"That's sort of my little, I guess, way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webb_Simpson", "type": "person", "score": 5, {"uri": "2024-05-349324990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "17:21:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T17:21:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T17:13:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240508-mcilroy-won-t-return-to-pga-policy-board-simpson-to-stay", "title": "McIlroy won't return to PGA Policy Board, Simpson to stay", "body": "Washington (AFP) - Rory McIlroy will not be returning to the PGA Tour Policy Board, the four-time major winner said on Wednesday, with Webb Simpson staying on the decision-making panel.\n\nSpeaking on the eve of the PGA Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow in Charlotte, North Carolina, McIlroy said some other board members had concerns about his return after stepping down from the board last year.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations. Sort of reminded me partly why I didn't (stay),\" McIlroy said. \"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before.\n\n\"There was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\n\n\"I think the best course of action is ... Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he has gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nThe board includes players Tiger Woods, Adam Scott, Jordan Spieth, Patrick Cantlay and Peter Malnati. Cantlay and Spieth have had past disputes with McIlroy over golf's future direction.\n\nMcIlroy had been expected to return after 2012 US Open winner Simpson said he was stepping down to spend more time with his family.\n\nInstead, according to McIlroy, Simpson will complete his term, which expires in 2025.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was -- I wouldn't say it was rejected,\" McIlroy said. \"It was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nThe board remains in talks about finalizing a merger deal between the PGA Tour and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) -- backers of the rival LIV Golf League -- from a framework agreement announced last June.\n\n\"I'm still optimistic,\" McIlroy said. \"I think Webb staying on is a really good thing. He has got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great. My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen.\"\n\nTalks with an original December deadline have dragged months beyond, the frustrations of slow to no progress having been among the factors that sparked McIlroy's exit.\n\n\"I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said.\n\nMcIlroy compared the situation to the Good Friday Agreement that ended unrest in Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"That's my little way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\nYears down the line\n\nMcIlroy cited restoring PGA status for players who jumped for rich LIV deals and a potential global schedule as issues that will require compromise.\n\n\"If we go to more of a global schedule, do the American players that are used to playing all their golf in America want to travel outside of the States 12 times a year to play tournament golf? That's a consideration,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"Would it be palatable to the rest of the (PGA) membership if (defectors to LIV) come back after seeing out their contract and they've financially got ahead by potentially hundreds of millions of dollars over the people that stayed? That's a consideration.\n\n\"It's not really about the here and now. It is a little bit, but it's also about how does this thing look 10, 15, 20 years down the line.\"", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8118665075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-09", "time": "07:25:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-09T07:25:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-09T07:25:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/09/pga-tour-board-unreceptive-to-mcilroys-return/", "title": "PGA Tour board unreceptive to McIlroy's return", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- Rory McIlroy won't be returning to the PGA Tour board, saying Wednesday that a plan to replace Webb Simpson was met with resistance from board members.\n\nSimpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat -- but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said of potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"\n\nRory McIlroy, of Northern Ireland, standing, and his teammate Shane Lowry, of Ireland, line up a shot on the 17th green during the final round of the PGA Zurich Classic golf tournament at TPC Louisiana in Avondale, La., Sunday, April 28, 2024. "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Rules_and_Etiquette", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Golf/Rules and Etiquette", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 85}], "image": "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/05/08/23/84635591-0-image-m-46_1715206789436.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9549930", "eventUri": "eng-9549930", "location": null, "extractedDates": {"uri": "8117876134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:13:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:13:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:13:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/rory-mcilroy-won-t-return-180304841.html", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't return to PGA Tour Policy Board after 'uncomfortable' response from players", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- The PGA Tour's best players are at Quail Hollow this week for the sixth of eight $20 million signature events this season, but the early discussion so far at the 2024 Wells Fargo Championship has been focused off the course.\n\nPGA Tour Policy Board member Webb Simpson had planned to step down from his role and have Rory McIlroy - who resigned from the board back in November - take his place. After some \"complicated\" and \"messy\" discussions, Simpson will see out his term which ends in 2025 after players voiced their concerns about McIlroy returning.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations,\" McIlroy said with a coy smile, noting how the discussions partly reminded him of why he left the policy board in the first place. \"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before.\"\n\n\"There was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason,\" he added. \"I think the best course of action is if, you know, there's some people on there that aren't comfortable with me coming back on, then I think Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing. I put my hand up to help and it was -- I wouldn't say it was rejected, it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson contradicted McIlroy no less than an hour later and denied any negative sentiment towards the world No. 2's potential return to the board.\n\n\"I think the players on the board were very supportive of him being more involved, and in those conversations I think they all see the vital role he plays not only on the PGA Tour, but he's a DP World Tour member and they're such an important piece in the game of golf and our Tour,\" said Simpson, who also noted he didn't get any sense that McIlroy wasn't welcomed. \"So his perspective is tremendous to us. He's a global player, always has been, so I just think his views are important, and the other guys feel the same.\"\n\nRory McIlroy of Northern Ireland in action during the Pro Am event at Quail Hollow Country Club on May 09, 2024 in Charlotte, North Carolina. (Photo by Andrew Redington/Getty Images)\n\nMcIlroy, who has been on the front lines for the PGA Tour in its battle with LIV Golf, joined the board in 2022 and was supposed to serve out his term until the end of this year until he abruptly resigned late last fall. McIlroy was then replaced by Jordan Spieth via a board vote. After sticking up for the Tour for the better half of two years, his decision to bail on the board didn't sit well with his colleagues.\n\n\"He was very clear that it was too much for him. He had business dealings, he has a kid, he wants to focus on his game. Trust me, I get it. But once you quit, you're not getting back,\" Kevin Streelman, a former member of the policy board who ran against McIlroy for Player Advisory Council chairman, told Golfweek. \"I wouldn't quit on something that you were elected to by your peers. To want back in is peculiar.\"\n\nSince he left the board, McIlroy has been adamant and outspoken on why the Tour needs to get a deal done with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund - LIV's financial backer - in order to reunite the game.\n\n\"Golf and the PGA Tour has been so good to me over the years, I just feel like it's my obligation or duty to try to give back and try to set the next generation of players up like we were set up by the previous generation,\" McIlroy said of his reasoning to try and rejoin the board after stepping down. \"I think there's a responsibility with every generation to try to leave the Tour, leave the place that you're playing in a bit of a better spot than it was before. That's what it's about.\"\n\nDespite being stiff-armed out of consideration, McIlroy is \"still optimistic\" a deal will get done and believes Simpson staying on \"is a really good thing.\"\n\n\"I think he's got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great,\" McIlroy explained. \"My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen. Yeah, I'm really happy that Webb has made that decision to stay on and serve out the rest of his term.\"\n\nAs a 35-year-old from Northern Ireland, McIlroy made an interesting comparison of the current state of professional golf to the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland and Ireland in the 1990s.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get (a deal) done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" he explained. \"I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"\n\n\"That's sort of how I -- it's my little I guess way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\nThe Tour's Chief Competitions Officer Tyler Dennis wasn't able to provide a material update on the status of the conversations between the PIF and the Tour, but did note the {"uri": "2024-05-349587248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:27:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:27:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:30:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/8/rory-mcilroy-wont-rejoin-pga-tour-board-says-other/", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't rejoin PGA Tour board, says others were 'uncomfortable' with his potential return", "body": "Simpson, one of six player-directors, recently offered to give up his seat - but only if McIlroy were to replace him. McIlroy would have needed board approval to be reinstated to a position that he resigned from last November.\n\nBut McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said of potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy - or even worse, apathetic - with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think - I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", {"uri": "8117867115", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:06:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:06:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://golfweek.usatoday.com/2024/05/08/rory-mcilroy-pga-tour-policy-board-webb-simpson/", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't return to PGA Tour Policy Board after 'uncomfortable' response from players", "body": "CHARLOTTE, N.C. -- The PGA Tour's best players are at Quail Hollow this week for the sixth of eight $20 million signature events this season, but the early discussion so far at the 2024 Wells Fargo Championship has been focused off the course.\n\nPGA Tour Policy Board member Webb Simpson had planned to step down from his role and have Rory McIlroy - who resigned from the board back in November - take his place. After some \"complicated\" and \"messy\" discussions, Simpson will see out his term which ends in 2025 after players voiced their concerns about McIlroy returning.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations,\" McIlroy said with a coy smile, noting how the discussions partly reminded him of why he left the policy board in the first place. \"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before.\"\n\n\"There was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason,\" he added. \"I think the best course of action is if, you know, there's some people on there that aren't comfortable with me coming back on, then I think Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing. I put my hand up to help and it was -- I wouldn't say it was rejected, it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson contradicted McIlroy no less than an hour later and denied any negative sentiment towards the world No. 2's potential return to the board.\n\n\"I think the players on the board were very supportive of him being more involved, and in those conversations I think they all see the vital role he plays not only on the PGA Tour, but he's a DP World Tour member and they're such an important piece in the game of golf and our Tour,\" said Simpson, who also noted he didn't get any sense that McIlroy wasn't welcomed. \"So his perspective is tremendous to us. He's a global player, always has been, so I just think his views are important, and the other guys feel the same.\"\n\nRory McIlroy of Northern Ireland in action during the Pro Am event at Quail Hollow Country Club on May 09, 2024 in Charlotte, North Carolina. (Photo by Andrew Redington/Getty Images)\n\nMcIlroy, who has been on the front lines for the PGA Tour in its battle with LIV Golf, joined the board in 2022 and was supposed to serve out his term until the end of this year until he abruptly resigned late last fall. McIlroy was then replaced by Jordan Spieth via a board vote. After sticking up for the Tour for the better half of two years, his decision to bail on the board didn't sit well with his colleagues.\n\n\"He was very clear that it was too much for him. He had business dealings, he has a kid, he wants to focus on his game. Trust me, I get it. But once you quit, you're not getting back,\" Kevin Streelman, a former member of the policy board who ran against McIlroy for Player Advisory Council chairman, told Golfweek. \"I wouldn't quit on something that you were elected to by your peers. To want back in is peculiar.\"\n\nSince he left the board, McIlroy has been adamant and outspoken on why the Tour needs to get a deal done with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund - LIV's financial backer - in order to reunite the game.\n\n\"Golf and the PGA Tour has been so good to me over the years, I just feel like it's my obligation or duty to try to give back and try to set the next generation of players up like we were set up by the previous generation,\" McIlroy said of his reasoning to try and rejoin the board after stepping down. \"I think there's a responsibility with every generation to try to leave the Tour, leave the place that you're playing in a bit of a better spot than it was before. That's what it's about.\"\n\nDespite being stiff-armed out of consideration, McIlroy is \"still optimistic\" a deal will get done and believes Simpson staying on \"is a really good thing.\"\n\n\"I think he's got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great,\" McIlroy explained. \"My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen. Yeah, I'm really happy that Webb has made that decision to stay on and serve out the rest of his term.\"\n\nAs a 35-year-old from Northern Ireland, McIlroy made an interesting comparison of the current state of professional golf to the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland and Ireland in the 1990s.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get (a deal) done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" he explained. \"I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"\n\n\"That's sort of how I -- it's my little I guess way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\nThe Tour's Chief Competitions Officer Tyler Dennis wasn't able to provide a material update on the status of the conversations between the PIF and the Tour, but did note the discussions are still ongoing and positive.\n\nDespite increased criticism, Webb Simpson defends PGA Tour sponsor exemption for 2024 Wells Fargo Championship Photos: Wells Fargo Championship 2024 at {"uri": "8118146441", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "22:30:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T22:30:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T22:29:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.foxsports.com.au/golf/golf-news-rory-mcilroy-blocked-from-returning-to-pga-tour-policy-board-latest-liv-golf-patrick-cantlay/news-story/25eae690096b58c3a003d387b6df5697", "title": "'Destroying the sport from the inside': PGA chaos as Rory blocked from returning to top board", "body": "Rory McIlroy will not be returning to the PGA Tour Policy Board, the four-time major winner said on Wednesday, with Webb Simpson staying on the decision-making panel.\n\nSpeaking on the eve of the PGA Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow in Charlotte, North Carolina, McIlroy said some other board members had concerns about his return after stepping down from the board last year.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations. Sort of reminded me partly why I didn't (stay),\" McIlroy said. \"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before.\n\n\"There was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\n\n\"I think the best course of action is ... Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he has gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nWatch every round of the PGA Tour LIVE & Exclusive on Fox Sports, available on Kayo. New to Kayo? Start Your Free Trial Today >\n\nThe board includes players Tiger Woods, Adam Scott, Jordan Spieth, Patrick Cantlay and Peter Malnati. Cantlay and Spieth have had past disputes with McIlroy over golf's future direction - and multiple reports have said that Cantlay played a key role in denying McIlroy's return.\n\nMcIlroy had been expected to return after 2012 US Open winner Simpson said he was stepping down to spend more time with his family.\n\nInstead, according to McIlroy, Simpson will complete his term, which expires in 2025.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was -- I wouldn't say it was rejected,\" McIlroy said. \"It was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nMORE NEWS\n\nShock PGA move sparks LIV invasion as rogue Aussie's nod ushers in new era\n\nThe board remains in talks about finalising a merger deal between the PGA Tour and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) -- backers of the rival LIV Golf League -- from a framework agreement announced last June.\n\n\"I'm still optimistic,\" McIlroy said. \"I think Webb staying on is a really good thing. He has got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great. My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen.\"\n\nTalks with an original December deadline have dragged months beyond, the frustrations of slow to no progress having been among the factors that sparked McIlroy's exit.\n\n\"I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said.\n\nBut the ongoing failure to secure a deal to reunite golf has sparked outrage. Journalist Dan Rapaport tweeted: \"11 months after Framework Agreement and news of the day is top players bickering. No PGA Tour-PIF deal in sight. Talent split between tours.\n\n\"The last 3 years have been a case study in how to destroy a sport from the inside. And the players are richer than ever. Hard to stomach.\"\n\nMcIlroy compared the situation to the Good Friday Agreement that ended unrest in Ireland and Northern Ireland in the 1990s.\n\n\"Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"That's my little way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\nMcIlroy cited restoring PGA status for players who jumped for rich LIV deals and a potential global schedule as issues that will require compromise.\n\n\"If we go to more of a global schedule, do the American players that are used to playing all their golf in America want to travel outside of the States 12 times a year to play tournament golf? That's a consideration,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"Would it be palatable to the rest of the (PGA) membership if (defectors to LIV) come back after seeing out their contract and they've financially got ahead by potentially hundreds of millions of dollars over the people that stayed? That's a consideration.\n\n\"It's not really about the here and now. It is a little bit, but it's also about how does this thing look 10, 15, 20 years down the line.\"", "source": {"uri": "foxsports.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fox Sports"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8117892178", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "18:27:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T18:27:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T18:27:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/mcilroy-wont-return-to-pga-policy-board-simpson-to-stay/article_7d1456b4-6baa-526d-bc56-700ac5e7bb31.html", "title": "McIlroy won't return to PGA Policy Board, Simpson to stay", "body": "Rory McIlroy will not be returning to the PGA Tour Policy Board, the four-time major winner said on Wednesday, with Webb Simpson staying on the decision-making panel.\n\nSpeaking on the eve of the PGA Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow in Charlotte, North Carolina, McIlroy said some other board members had concerns about his return after stepping down from the board last year.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations. Sort of reminded me partly why I didn't (stay),\" McIlroy said. \"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before.\n\n\"There was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\n\n\"I think the best course of action is ... Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he has gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nThe board includes players Tiger Woods, Adam Scott, Jordan Spieth, Patrick Cantlay and Peter Malnati. Cantlay and Spieth have had past disputes with McIlroy over golf's future direction.\n\nMcIlroy had been expected to return after 2012 US Open winner Simpson said he was stepping down to spend more time with his family.\n\nInstead, according to McIlroy, Simpson will complete his term, which expires in 2025.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was -- I wouldn't say it was rejected,\" McIlroy said. \"It was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nThe board remains in talks about finalizing a merger deal between the PGA Tour and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) -- backers of the rival LIV Golf League -- from a framework agreement announced last June.\n\n\"I'm still optimistic,\" McIlroy said. \"I think Webb staying on is a really good thing. He has got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great. My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen.\"\n\nMore from this section Why fire departments need money for rescue boats Death Toll From Flooding in Southern Brazil Rises to 85 - TaiwanPlus News 'Survivor' exhibit highlights 18 local Holocaust survivors\n\nTalks with an original December deadline have dragged months beyond, the frustrations of slow to no progress having been among the factors that sparked McIlroy's exit.\n\n\"I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said.\n\nMcIlroy compared the situation to the Good Friday Agreement that ended unrest in Ireland and Northern Ireland.\n\n\"Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"That's my little way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here. Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\n- Years down the line -\n\nMcIlroy cited restoring PGA status for players who jumped for rich LIV deals and a potential global schedule as issues that will require compromise.\n\n\"If we go to more of a global schedule, do the American players that are used to playing all their golf in America want to travel outside of the States 12 times a year to play tournament golf? {"uri": "8117572181", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "14:37:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T14:37:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T14:36:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://theathletic.com/5479648/2024/05/08/rory-mcilroy-pga-tour-policy-board-rejoin/", "title": "Rory McIlroy won't rejoin PGA Tour board", "body": "A PGA Tour policy board member attempted two weeks ago to resign from his seat with the specific caveat that Rory McIlroy rejoin the powerful group. Now, it appears the board is resisting Rory McIlroy's return.\n\nMcIlroy told reporters Wednesday the process for his return was complicated and not all parties supported it after McIlroy resigned from his own board seat just six months earlier. In turn, Webb Simpson, the man who hoped to step down to let McIlroy back in, is expected to keep his board seat for the remainder of his term.\n\n\"I think there was -- there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason,\" McIlroy said after a pro-am round at the Wells Fargo Championship in Charlotte. \"I think the best course of action is if, you know, there's some people on there that aren't comfortable with me coming back on, then I think Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nMcIlroy was the most vocal and public face of the PGA Tour in its war against LIV -- often criticizing the Saudi-funded league and players who left the PGA Tour to join it -- until the tour surprisingly announced a framework agreement to team up with the Public Investment Fund of Saudi Arabia on June 6, 2023. After that announcement, he referred to himself as a \"sacrificial lamb\" and took a large step back from his prominent public role. He resigned from the PGA Tour policy board in November, and Jordan Spieth took his place.\n\nThe policy board is a collection of 11 voting members that help decide the future of the PGA Tour with six seats reserved for player directors. Shortly after McIlroy's resignation, Sports Illustrated reported McIlroy (who was primarily fighting to spread wealth throughout the tour) lost a power battle to the bloc of Patrick Cantlay, Tiger Woods and Spieth, all of whom were pushing for more money and power for top players.\n\nSince his departure, McIlroy has reactivated his voice but shifted his message toward unification with LIV and bringing all the best players together. He rubbed people the wrong way, criticizing Spieth publicly for saying the PGA Tour didn't \"need\" the Saudis. He consistently made comments about the desire for money ruining the sport. He then got in an awkward incident at the Players Championship with playing partners Spieth and Viktor Hovland.\n\nMcIlroy rejoining the board would have undoubtedly created an interesting dynamic.\n\n\"I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said Wednesday.\n\nWhen reports first surfaced about Simpson's letter of resignation at the Zurich Classic in April, McIlroy said of a potential return: \"I think I can be helpful. I don't think there's been much progress made in the last eight months, and I was hopeful that there would be.\"\n\nAt the time, most assumed McIlroy's return would be a simple process, but there isn't much if any precedent for a board member requesting who takes their place. McIlroy made several comments acknowledging the need for the board to approve it.\n\n\"But only if people want me involved, I guess,\" he said. \"When Webb and I talked and he talked about potentially coming off the board, I said, look, if it was something that other people wanted, I would gladly take that seat, and that was the conversation that we had.\"\n\nMcIlroy said his return wasn't completely rejected, but the process was complicated and there's no hard feelings. He remains optimistic a deal with PIF will get done, in part because Simpson is keeping his board seat.\n\n\"I think he's got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great,\" McIlroy said. \"My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen.\"", "source": {"uri": "theathletic.com", {"uri": "8118172713", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "23:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T23:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T23:00:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/08/sports/rory-mcilroy-pga-tour-liv-golf/", "title": "After resistance, Rory McIlroy won't rejoin PGA Tour policy board - The Boston Globe", "body": "But McIlroy said ahead of the Wells Fargo Championship that conversations surrounding his potential return became \"pretty complicated and messy,\" which reminded him of why he left in the first place.\n\n\"I think with the way it happened it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said. \"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\"\n\nMcIlroy's reinstatement would have been viewed as a chance to help improve the PGA Tour's stalled negotiations with the Saudi financial backers of LIV Golf.\n\nThe world's No. 2 player said when he stepped down, he could no longer commit the time and energy that board work required with the PGA Tour trying to finalize an agreement with the Public Investment Fund.\n\nUnable to finalize a deal by the end of last year, the PGA Tour brought in Strategic Sports Group -- a consortium led by Fenway Sports Group -- as a minority investor. That deal could be worth as much as $3 billion.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, (but) it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there,\" McIlroy said of potentially returning the board. \"So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nSimpson said he now plans to finish out his three-year term on the board. He said he offered to give up his seat to McIlroy because he's a \"global superstar\" and would give Europeans a needed voice in major tour decisions.\n\n\"Rory always had great ideas of how do we move forward, how do we get the love and attention from fans back from where we had it maybe two years ago, how do we grow our business, all things related to the PGA Tour,\" Simpson said.\n\nBut there are some on the board who remain at odds with the four-time major champion after McIlroy changed his views about LIV Golf in recent months, suggesting that LIV players be allowed to return to the PGA Tour without penalty.\n\nMcIlroy also disagreed in February with Jordan Spieth's comments that a deal with PIF was not needed because of the SSG investment, although it would help with unification.\n\nMcIlroy suggested one solution for growing the game would be going to a more global schedule that includes more tournaments overseas, although he questioned whether American players would want to travel out of the United States for a dozen events.\n\nRegardless, McIlroy remains bothered by the state of the game and wants to see a resolution for the good of the fans, a growing faction of which have become unhappy -- or even worse, apathetic -- with the splintering of players on two watered-down tours.\n\nMcIlroy said it's all about finding a compromise for both sides, even though neither side may walk away completely happy.\n\n\"I would say I'm impatient because I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective ... I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said. \"And I just think -- I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process in the '90s and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\"", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rory_McIlroy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rory McIlroy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LIV_Golf", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"uri": "8117690015", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:54:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:54:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:54:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/sport/golf/rory-mcilroy-not-return-pga-32765178", "title": "Rory not returning to PGA board as he likens LIV merger to Good Friday Agreement", "body": "Rory McIlroy will be returning to the PGA Tour policy board after the prospect of his return reopened \"old wounds\".\n\nMcIlroy was rumoured to be in line to replace Webb Simpson and was hopeful that he could play a part in speeding up a deal between the PGA Tour, DP World Tour and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF), which bankrolls the LIV Golf League.\n\nHowever, the world number two has revealed that a \"subset\" of Tour members were against his return to the board. McIlroy insisted that he had no issue with not being wanted back, and that he was ready to move on.\n\nREAD MORE: Rory McIlroy was struggling to have fun on PGA Tour until being taught 'great lesson'\n\n\"It got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before,\" McIlroy said.\n\n\"I think there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason.\n\n\"I think the best course of action is Webb just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\n\n\"So yeah, I put my hand up to help and it was, I wouldn't say it was rejected, it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on.\"\n\nOn the topic of the merger between the PGA Tour, DP World Tour and LIV, McIlroy likened the situation to the Good Friday Agreement and believes that while a deal will inevitably get done, it will probably upset people on all sides.\n\n\"I think we've got this window of opportunity to get it done, because both sides from a business perspective I wouldn't say need to get it done, but it makes sense,\" McIlroy said\n\n\"I sort of liken it to like when Northern Ireland went through the peace process and the Good Friday Agreement, neither side was happy. Catholics weren't happy, Protestants weren't happy, but it brought peace and then you just sort of learn to live with whatever has been negotiated, right?\n\n\"That was in 1998 and 20, 25, 30 years ahead, my generation doesn't know any different. It's just this is what it's always been like and we've never known anything but peace.\n\n\"It's my little way of trying to think about it and trying to make both sides see that there could be a compromise here.\n\n\"Yeah, it's probably not going to feel great for either side, but if it's a place where the game of golf starts to thrive again and we can all get back together, then I think that's ultimately a really good thing.\"\n\nMcIlroy admits persuading American players to contest a more global schedule and the question of LIV players returning to the PGA Tour are issues which need to be resolved, but believes a deal can be done.\n\n\"I'm still optimistic,\" he added. \"I think Webb staying on is a really good thing. I think he's got a really balanced voice in all of this and I think he sees the bigger picture, which is great.\n\n\"My fear was if Webb stepped off and it wasn't me that was going in his place, what could potentially happen. I'm really happy that Webb has made that decision to stay on and serve out the rest of his term.\"\n\nGet the latest sports headlines straight to your inbox by signing up for free email alerts.",
