Pga Memorial Tournament Round 3\n\nPro golfer Rory McIlroy has been one of the main PGA Tour voices speaking out against LIV Golf. He, along with Tiger Woods, has been the main steady force that has helped to keep the tour afloat despite being offered millions to jump ship.\n\nThe pair have been rewarded for their loyalty. However, Mcllroy has stepped back as PGA spokesman in recent months and has even decided not to be part of the PGA Tour board and stepped down.\n\nNow, he wants back in but some board members don't want him to rejoin the board. This appears to be because he has taken a softened stance against LIV Golf, which has turned some board members off.\n\n\"There's been a lot of conversations. Sort of reminded me partly why I didn't [stay on the board in the first place],\" he said, per Golf Digest. \"I think it just, it got pretty complicated and pretty messy and I think with the way it happened, I think it opened up some old wounds and scar tissue from things that have happened before ... there was a subset of people on the board that were maybe uncomfortable with me coming back on for some reason. \"I think the best course of action is if, you know, there's some people on there that aren't comfortable with me coming back on, then I think Webb (Simpson) just stays on and sees out his term, and I think he's gotten to a place where he's comfortable with doing that and I just sort of keep doing what I'm doing.\"\n\nAlthough he volunteered to help and was rejected, Mcllroy says there were no hard feelings.\n\n\"I put my hand up to help and it was ... I wouldn't say it was rejected, it was a complicated process to get through to put me back on there. So that's all fine, no hard feelings and we'll all move on,\" Mcllroy said.\n\nWebb Simpson seems to be the person leading the way to try and put McIlroy back on the board, but detractors include Patrick Cantlay.\n\nYou have to wonder if is it a mistake in not to let one of the world's best golfers and a huge advocate for the PGA Tour not back on the board. It could open the door for LIV Golf to make a serious run at him again. Mcllroy seems to be steadfast in his loyalty to the PGA but that all could be tested.\n\nHe seems to be leaning more and more into this merger with LIV Golf. Even though it might won't happen, it also may not be a shock if Mcllroy decides to eventually shift allegiances if the wind blows the right way. The PGA Board better hope they are doing the right thing because right now, they are playing a dangerous game.", "source": {"uri": "thecomeback.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Comeback"}, {"uri": "8117681685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "15:48:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T15:48:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T15:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://talksport.com/sport/1859611/rory-mcilroy-approach-quail-hollow-wells-fargo-championship/", "title": "Rory McIlroy explains new approach as he heads into Wells Fargo Championship", "body": "The Wells Fargo Championship has been kind to Rory McIlroy over the years.\n\nThe 35-year-old heads into the tournament at Quail Hollow this week having won the event on three previous occasions (2010, 2015, 2021).\n\nThe Northern Irishman got back to winning ways recently after triumphing at the Zurich Classic in New Orleans with fellow Irishman Shane Lowry.\n\nMcIlroy's victory at the Zurich Classic was his first on the PGA Tour since the Genesis Scottish Open in 2023 and the four-time major winner feels revitalised going into the Wells Fargo Championship this week.\n\n\"The week in New Orleans did me the world of good just in terms of the fun element,\" McIlroy said after playing a practice round at Quail Hollow.\n\n\"It was a lot of fun; we had a great time, regardless of the result.\n\n\"But then, obviously, the result was a bonus, too, and getting the win with Shane. So, yeah, it was a great week.\n\n\"I'm so glad that we were able to do it and play, and, yeah, it definitely makes me excited about the rest of the year now.\n\nMcIlroy has been famously stuck on four majors for ten years, with his last glory coming at the 2024 PGA Championship\n\nHe finished 16 shots behind Scottie Scheffler at The Masters last month as another major passed him by.\n\nNevertheless, he has continued to rack up wins on tour and is the first player to reach 25 PGA Tour wins (regular season events and majors) since 2005.\n\nMcIlroy admitted the major setbacks have been tough to swallow but his first win of 2024 served as a 'great lesson' in remembering to have fun on the course.\n\n\"I think when you're going through a spell of golf where you're not getting the results that you want, it's hard to have fun, right?\" he said.\n\n\"It's hard to keep your enthusiasm. It's hard to keep that positive mindset, week in, week out.\n\n\"That was my fourth week in a row, and I was saying to my team last week, it's a great lesson for me that when things aren't going great, sometimes it's not about going back home and working on your game and standing on the range.\n\n\"It's about trying to play, and play through it and understand what your misses are and how to manage.\n\n\"It was a good lesson to me that sometimes just to keep going is the right thing to do, and to keep playing and to keep working on what you're working on and having faith that it is all {"uri": "2024-05-348946640", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-08", "time": "11:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-08T11:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-08T11:31:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3686274588108063, "url": "https://www.sportskeeda.com/golf/news-we-drank-nice-stuff-good-time-shane-lowry-details-zurich-classic-win-celebration-rory-mcilroy", "title": "Shane Lowry says he 'drank some nice stuff' with Rory McIlroy to celebrate their Zurich Classic win", "body": "Shane Lowry has revealed that he and Rory McIlroy celebrated their Zurich Classic win a few days later by drinking some 'good stuff'. He added that it was important to celebrate the good days too considering he had won only seven times in 16 years.\n\nBoth Lowry and McIlroy are at the Quail Hollow Club this week for the Wells Fargo Championship. This will be their first start since their win at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans two weeks ago. Playing together for the first time, the duo beat Chad Ramey and Martin Trainer in the playoff.\n\nDuring the Tuesday press conference of the Wells Fargo Championship, Shane Lowry said it was lovely to get a win since this was his first win on the PGA Tour in five years. Speaking about the post-win celebration, he revealed he returned home on Sunday night and McIlroy also had to go somewhere on Monday. So they decided to meet up on Wednesday and enjoy their recent triumph.\n\n\"We had a pretty good Wednesday night,\" he added. \"We drank some nice stuff and had a good time and we celebrated our win which you should do. I've been on tour I've been playing 16 years and I've only won seven times. So you got to celebrate the good times too.\"\n\nThis was Shane Lowry's third win on the PGA Tour and first since the Open Championship 2019. His last professional win before the Zurich Classic was the BMW PGA Championship in 2022.\n\n\"I couldn't believe he was doing it,\" Shane Lowry reflects on Rory McIlroy's singing during the Zurich Classic win celebration\n\nDuring the post-win celebration at the Zurich Classic of New Orleans, Rory McIlroy was spotted singing 'Don't Stop Believing' in front of a huge crowd. During the Tuesday press conference, Shane Lowry spoke about the incident.\n\n\"I couldn't believe he was doing it, to be honest,\" he said. \"I was just standing on the side. Yeah, he kind of got blindsided into doing it, so fair play to him.\"\n\nWhen asked to rate McIlroy's singing skills, the Irishman responded that he was a better golfer than the singer.\n\nThe 37-year-old golfer will now seen competing at the Wells Fargo Championship, which commences on Thursday, May 9. He is grouped with Wyndham Clark and Xander Schauffele for the opening round.
